{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2972580,"name":"Joe Johnson","username":"Joe_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_johnson/{size}/156076_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-20T02:25:40.390Z","cooked":"

As I have shamelessly plugged over and over again, Team 88 is having a second beta test of our Diff Swerve Modules focusing on getting the controls library to the point that relatively inexperienced teams can have the benefits of a high performance swerve drive, right out of the box. Diff Swerve Beta2, The Controls & Software Boogaloo*.

Part of getting to the top of that hill is picking a path that is likely to succeed.

I have heard a lot of folks talk about using a State Space approach. I am favorably inclined toward this path because I believe that it offers a lot of advantages for controlling MIMO (multi input multi output) systems.

BUT… I have a lot of holes in my knowledge. State Space looks complicated and comes in a near in infinite variety of flavors & colors. Beyond that, there’s specialized terminology, some high powered math, modelling, observers, and filters, and bears (oh my!).

How do we follow the Yellow Brick Road with all that waiting to challenge our Brains, Courage, and Heart?

Can someone sketch out in broad brush strokes what an a state space control scheme for Swerve would look like? Maybe point out some of the major obstacles to successful implementation might be? Advantages?

Given some of the limitations of the FRC control system, does it make sense to have some sort of hybrid control where the various swerve motors are running their own PID loops with a State Space control riding on top?

I realize this is a huge topic and can involve a lot of grad level math. Even so, I hope that the CD community can rise to the challenge and help bring some clarity to this foggy area.

Cheers,
Dr. Joe J.

*Seriously. DM me if your team is willing to trade some free swerve hardware for controls and coding work.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-20T02:28:02.910Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":457,"reads":359,"readers_count":358,"score":2461.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Joe Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/diff-swerve-beta2-the-controls-software-boogaloo/396430","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Diff Swerve Beta2, The Controls & Software Boogaloo","clicks":59}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":6,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2972585,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-20T02:43:16.517Z","cooked":"

Adding a second voice that I’d be interested in increasing my knowledge in this space, and am just barely starting to stick a toe into the water here.

The excessively simple understanding I’ve accumulated over the years: If you can get your physical system expressed in a standard, Matrix-based format, a bunch of well-proven tools for designing good controllers are suddenly available.

The challenge (aside from establishing initial understanding) is that all-important action of describing your system in that format.

One thing I’ll throw out there - the long-unfinished and unproven PR simulating swerve drive behavior doesn’t yet use state-space modeling paradigms to describe a swerve drive’s behavior. There’s still work to do that.

I’m also not entirely certain it will go… nicely. Namely because the wheel/ground friction model is non-linear… in this case, specifically models stick/slip with an if/else statement.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-20T02:43:52.704Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":325,"readers_count":324,"score":95.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib/pull/3374","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":31}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2972593,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-20T03:32:09.040Z","cooked":"

If you plan to capture how the other modules affect each other’s rotation and velocities, the Lagrangian and the sum-of-forces/sum-of-torques analysis are both going to be nightmares.

gerthworm:

I’m also not entirely certain it will go… nicely. Namely because the wheel/ground friction model is non-linear… in this case, specifically models stick/slip with an if/else statement.

Piecewise models are fun too…

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-20T03:32:09.040Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":306,"readers_count":305,"score":156.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/3","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973105,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-23T19:24:19.511Z","cooked":"

I think trying to build a single model to determine the eight motor inputs needed to get x, y, and theta speeds is going to be pretty infeasible because of the complexity of the friction interactions with all of the wheels. That being said, it seems reasonable to use traditional inverse kinematics methods to determine the azimuth angles and drive speeds for each module then use the state space model developed by @pietroglyph to determine the motor voltages.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-23T19:24:19.511Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":63.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Ari Meles-Braverman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/paper-a-state-space-model-for-a-differential-swerve/396496","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Paper: A State-Space Model for a Differential Swerve","clicks":49}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/4","custom_user_title":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973116,"name":"UnofficialForth","username":"UnofficialForth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unofficialforth/{size}/167902_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-24T00:31:12.714Z","cooked":"

Could we simplify the problem to an intermediate state if we add the constraint that each drive pod must be at the same gear ratio at any given time? We could then work from there.

Edit: I got terminology mixed up in my head, and was thinking about a CVT swerve, not a differential swerve

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-24T00:49:29.403Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":210,"readers_count":209,"score":52.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"UnofficialForth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29982,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC Team 4272 Mentor | World's FLL Emcee"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/5","custom_user_title":"FRC Team 4272 Mentor | World's FLL Emcee","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973119,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-24T00:38:36.627Z","cooked":"

Before trying to solve the problem, someone should try to measure how big it is. It seems to me that should be quite a bit simpler, and provide insight into whether a larger model is worth pursuing even in principle.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-24T00:38:36.627Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":76.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":29982,"username":"UnofficialForth","name":"UnofficialForth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unofficialforth/{size}/167902_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/6","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973120,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-24T00:48:23.336Z","cooked":"

I’m assuming, for fully validating a particular model, part of this is going to involve data collection of actual pose on a field, relative to inputs (motor voltage x 8 ?).

I would gander to say a motion capture setup might be in order?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-24T00:48:23.336Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":200,"readers_count":199,"score":70.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973122,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-24T01:03:49.554Z","cooked":"

The first thing we tried for a WPILib swerve drive sim was a dynamical model for the wheel headings and velocities, swerve forward kinematics to combine them into a chassis movement, then swerve inverse kinematics to move the module states toward a valid solution that behaved as if friction existed. It didn’t drive realistically.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-24T01:14:20.346Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":189,"readers_count":188,"score":92.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":25012,"username":"AriMB","name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/8","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973137,"name":"D.Slobodzian","username":"D.Slobodzian","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/d6d6ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-24T04:25:05.247Z","cooked":"

There is also a paper about 4WIS/4WID(Swerve) that goes into the details of the dynamics and kinematics. There is some good information but by lack of knowledge might have added a bit of a roadblock on some of the calculations. It uses Lagrangians and as calcmogul stated it didn’t look clean in the slightest.
I will say if anyone is interested, these matrix outputs didn’t make sense to me as the dimensions didn’t add up.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-24T04:29:36.036Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":166,"readers_count":165,"score":48.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"D.Slobodzian","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/273310520_Kinematics_dynamics_and_control_design_of_4WIS4WID_mobile_robots","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":36}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33888,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973203,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-24T18:20:44.182Z","cooked":"
D.Slobodzian:

I will say if anyone is interested, these matrix outputs didn’t make sense to me as the dimensions didn’t add up.

I don’t see what the problem is. \overline{F} and \overline{\tau}_d are 8 \times 1; N, \overline{N}, J, J^\mathsf{T}, M, \overline{M}, and \overline{V}_m are 8 \times 8. \in tells you the dimensionality of the whole expression, not the right-most matrix.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2021-10-24T18:21:41.832Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":75.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396690,"topic_slug":"lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive","display_username":"Tyler Veness","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend"},"post_url":"/t/lets-talk-about-state-space-controls-approach-to-swerve-drive/396690/10","custom_user_title":"WPILib controls | Choreo optimizer backend","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973212,"name":"D.Slobodzian","username":"D.Slobodzian","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/d6d6ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-24T19:24:52.746Z","cooked":"

I understood that, but F is an 8 \times 1 vector and J is an 8 \times 11 matrix. So \overline{F} should be an 11 \times 1 vector, not 8 \times 1. The same issue with \overline{\tau}_d, please correct me if I’m wrong though.

Yea, looks like they’re referring to two different J matrices here. This lack of attention to detail happens a lot in academic papers, and it’s sad.
